    Systematic Optimization of Potent and Orally Bioavailable Purine Scaffold as a Dual Inhibitor of Toll-Like Receptors 7 and 9

    • Biswajit Kundu
      Biswajit Kundu
      Department of Organic and Medicinal Chemistry, CSIR—Indian Institute of Chemical Biology, 4 Raja S. C. Mullick Road, Kolkata 700032, West Bengal, India

    SUBJECTS:
    • Antagonists,

    • Aromatic compounds
    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    Several toll-like receptors (TLRs) reside inside endosomes of specific immune cells—among them, aberrant activation of TLR7 and TLR9 is implicated in myriad contexts of autoimmune diseases, making them promising therapeutic targets. However, small-molecule TLR7 and TLR9 antagonists are not yet available for clinical use. We illustrate here the importance of C2, C6, and N9 substitutions in the purine scaffold for antagonism to TLR7 and TLR9 through structure–activity relationship studies using cellular reporter assays and functional studies on primary human immune cells. Further in vitro and in vivo pharmacokinetic studies identified an orally bioavailable lead compound 29, with IC50 values of 0.08 and 2.66 μM against TLR9 and TLR7, respectively. Isothermal titration calorimetry excluded direct TLR ligand–antagonist interactions. In vivo antagonism efficacy against mouse TLR9 and therapeutic efficacy in a preclinical murine model of psoriasis highlighted the potential of compound 29 as a therapeutic candidate in relevant autoimmune contexts.

    Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The human innate immune system is the first line of defense against the invasion of pathogenic microorganisms. Toll-like receptors (TLRs), mostly expressed on antigen-presenting cells such as dendritic cells, are germline-encoded pattern recognition molecules that play key roles in innate immunity by regulating inflammation.(1−4) These innate immune receptors recognize conserved patterns associated with microbes, thus shaping the innate immune response in health and disease.(2,5,6) TLRs are transmembrane proteins composed of a ligand-binding ectodomain (ECD) with leucine-rich repeats (LRRs), a transmembrane domain, and an acytoplasmic TIR (Toll/IL-1 receptor) domain responsible for downstream signaling.(2,7,8) To date, four TLRs, namely, TLR3, 7, 8, and 9, have been identified in humans that are located inside the endosomal compartments (pH = 4.5–6.5) of the immune cells.(9−12) Among them, TLR7 and TLR8 recognize single-stranded RNA and TLR9 identifies hypomethylated CpG DNA motifs of both pathogenic origin and self-origin.(13−17) In humans, TLR7 and TLR9 are expressed selectively in plasmacytoid dendritic cells (pDCs) and B lymphocytes. Upon activation, they drive type I interferon (IFN) production from pDCs.(15,18,19)
    TLR activation is one of the initial defensive mechanisms utilized by the host to accumulate innate and subsequent adaptive immunity to fight invading pathogens.(20−22) However, when self-origin RNA or DNA molecules get access to endosomes and aberrantly activate TLR7/8/9, it initiates autoreactive inflammation. Considering the pathological role of TLRs in myriad chronic inflammatory disorders and autoimmune diseases, inhibiting endosomal TLRs is considered to be a novel therapeutic approach in these contexts.(23−28)
    TLR7/9 activation by self-nucleic acids leading to type I IFN induction in pDCs is a critical pathogenetic event in the development of autoimmune disorders. In fact, the role of aberrant TLR9 activation mediated by self-DNA molecules is well established in several systematic autoimmunities such as systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), Sjögren’s syndrome, psoriasis, and systemic sclerosis.(29−32) Hence, inhibition of TLR9 would play an important role in these clinical contexts. Both TLR7 and TLR9 are structurally similar to each other and initiate common downstream signaling upon activation. This results in the recruitment of the transcription factors NF-kB and IRF7, leading to the induction of inflammatory cytokines as well as type I IFNs. Hence, dual TLR7/9 antagonists would be useful for inhibiting aberrant signaling and type I IFN induction in disease conditions.(33,34)
    Exploration of potent and selective small-molecule TLR7 and TLR9 antagonists as therapeutic agents in several clinical contexts is of great interest, although as of now none of them are available for clinical use. Nonselective small-molecule CpG-52364 and oligonucleotide IMO-8400 manifesting both TLR7 and TLR9 antagonism entered clinical trial to evaluate their safety and efficacy in patients. However, CpG-52364 with the quinazoline scaffold failed to achieve the desired therapeutic outputs.(35,36) Some of the recent studies, including those from our group, have investigated the potency of benzoxazole and quinazoline scaffolds for the development of selective small-molecule TLR9 antagonists.(37−39) The design and development of small-molecule dual TLR7/9 and TLR9 antagonists have been primarily through empirical screening and an activity-guided approach.(40,41) In our previous study, we had demonstrated a chemical switch in the purine scaffold leading to a switch from TLR7 agonism to antagonism.(42) In the present study, we report a strategy for the design, synthesis, and study of the inhibitory activity of dual and potent TLR7/9 antagonists based on inhibition in primary human immune cells and reporter cells. Through structure–activity relationship (SAR) development, we identified the chemical features required for exhibiting dual TLR7/9 antagonism and subsequently how potent TLR9 antagonists can be obtained by modulating these features. We found that different substituents at C2, C6, and N9 positions in the purine scaffold act in a concerted manner to modify the inhibition of TLR7/9 activity as well as to impart selectivity against TLR7. We also report here the favorable in vitro and in vivo pharmacokinetic parameters, the in vivo TLR9 antagonism efficacy with a promising ADME profile, as well as the therapeutic potential in a preclinical murine model for the selected lead TLR7/9 antagonist (compound 29). Due to the structural similarity of endosomal TLRs, we also checked the TLR8 antagonism of compound 29 and did not find any significant inhibition up to 30 μM. Our systematic SAR can be considered as a template for the development of potent TLR7 and TLR9 antagonists (Figure 1).

    Chemistry

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The synthesis of the designed purine analogs is described in Schemes 1–3. Trisubstituted purine derivatives were prepared from commercially available 2-amino-6-chloropurine (2) using a conventional reaction strategy. To start with, we did selective C6 substitution of 2-amino-6-chloropurine with ethyl piperazine and cyclopentyl piperazine refluxing the reaction mixture for 4 h in acetonitrile (ACN) solvent using potassium carbonate as the base. This substitution reaction led to compounds 3 and 4, which were further substituted at the N9 position by heating with 1-(3-chloropropyl)-4-ethylpiperazine for 12 h in dimethylformamide (DMF) solvent using K2CO3 as the base to obtain two crucial intermediates 5 and 6, respectively. The amine group at the C2 position of intermediates 5 and 6 was then substituted with different benzyl groups via reductive amination, using appropriate aldehyde and sodium triacetoxyborohydride as a reducing agent, to obtain compounds 7–10 and 13–15. Compound 5 on treatment with 1,3-dibromopropane and sodium hydride provided compound 12 via SN2-mediated intramolecular cyclization reaction. Conventional amide formation reactions did not proceed at the C2 position due to the lack of nucleophilicity of the aromatic amine group. The C2 amino group was reacted with suitable carboxylic acids in the presence of POCl3 to provide compounds 11 and 16 in good yield (Scheme 1).
    As depicted in Scheme 2, we prepared purine analogs having small aromatic and aliphatic amide attached with the piperazine ring at the C6 position. First, the common intermediate 17 was synthesized by heating 2-amino-6-chloropurine (2) with 1-(3-chloropropyl)-4-ethylpiperazine at 80 °C for 12 h in DMF solvent using potassium carbonate as the base. Compound 17 was subjected to substitution reactions with suitable piperazine derivatives at the C6 position to obtain the prefinal compounds 18 and 19. A set of benzylamine-substituted purine derivatives at the C2 position was prepared by refluxing compound 18 with various para-substituted benzaldehydes in toluene for 12 h followed by reaction with sodium triacetoxyborohydride in DCE for 2 h. A similar reaction protocol was followed with compound 19 to afford compounds 24–26. Further, a pyrrolidine substituted purine analog at C2 was synthesized by heating compound 18 with 1,4-dibromobutane in the presence of sodium hydride as the base at 80 °C in DMF solvent for 12 h. In Scheme 3, a similar pattern of reaction sequence as described in Scheme 1 was followed to prepare two key intermediates 27 and 28. They were then subjected to reductive amination with the same set of aromatic aldehydes as already discussed before to obtain compounds 29–32. Finally, coupling reactions were performed by reacting intermediates 27 and 28 with p-dimethylaminomethyl benzoic acid in the presence of POCl3 to afford compounds 33 and 34.
    While synthesizing compound 27, there is a mechanistic possibility of forming both N7 and N9 isomers.(43) We performed two-dimensional (2D) NMR experiments (nuclear Overhauser effect spectroscopy (NOESY) and heteronuclear multiple bond correlation (HMBC)) to determine the regioselective substitution at the N9 position (Supporting Information, Page S65). We followed a similar procedure here to accomplish selective substitution at the N9 position in the purine scaffold over the N7 position.

    Results and Discussion

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Activity-Guided Design of Antagonists

    The rational development of the TLR7 and TLR9 antagonists was guided by their activity profile as measured in in vitro assays using TLR-reporter cell lines, namely, a TLR9 reporter HEK293 cell line as well as a TLR7 reporter HEK293 cell line, both of which report TLR-induced NF-κB activation in a colorimetric assay. CpGB and CL264 were used as TLR9 and TLR7 ligands, respectively, for the reporter assay, against which the inhibitory activity of the compounds (evaluated in terms of the IC50 value) was monitored (Supporting Information, Figures S1 and S2).(44) To further ensure the ability of these compounds to inhibit TLR9 in a more physiologically relevant setting, we studied the impact of the TLR9 antagonists (as selected on the basis of reporter assays) upon TLR9-induced IFNα induction in human peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs).(33,45) Of note here, pDCs are the major source of IFNα production in human PBMC culture in response to TLR9 activation (Supporting Information, Figure S4).
    In our previous findings,(42) we identified a chemical switch at the C2 position of the purine ring that could transform a TLR7 agonist into a TLR7 antagonist. Subsequent modifications had led to the development of potent TLR7 antagonist 1, which showed excellent selectivity against homologous endosomal TLR8.(42) Next, we checked the antagonistic potential of this compound against TLR9 since it is also localized in endosomes and shares the downstream signaling pathways as well as the functional outcomes.(46,47) Interestingly, TLR7 antagonist 1 (IC50 = 4.78 μM) was also found to inhibit TLR9 with an IC50 value of 1.18 μM. Thus, compound 1 can be considered as a dual TLR7/9 antagonist and served as the starting point of SAR development in the present study. To understand the structural requirements for the antagonism of TLR7 and TLR9,(33,37,48) we initially prepared a trisubstituted purine analog by substituting at the C2 position of the purine ring keeping the other substitutions constant. It was exciting to find that substituting the C2 position with a simple amine group alters the TLR7 vs TLR9 antagonism profile. Compound 5 with amine substitution at the C2 position exhibited potent TLR9 antagonism with an IC50 value of 0.26 μM, whereas TLR7 inhibition was observed at a much higher dose (IC50 = 16.22 μM) compared to the dose of compound 1 required for a similar antagonism (Table 1). Notably, we had previously reported the importance of C2 modification with the guanidine type of moiety in the quinazoline scaffold for the difference in TLR7 vs TLR9 antagonism.(39)
    Table 1. SAR Modification to the N9 Ethyl Piperazine Substituted Purine Scaffold
    a

    The IC50 values were derived from reporter assays using HEK293 cells transfected with hTLR9 (mean ± SD, n = 3).

    b

    The IC50 values were derived from reporter assays using HEK293 cells transfected with hTLR7 (mean ± SD, n = 3). TLR8 reporter assay of compound 16 was performed using HEK293 cells transfected with hTLR8 (mean ± SD, n = 3). The IC50 value was found to be >30 μM. Commercially available TLR agonists (CpGB for TLR9, CL264 for TLR7, and CL075 for TLR8) were used as positive controls.

    To visualize the reason behind the drastic change in TLR7 antagonism of compound 5, we built a homology model structure of human TLR7 and performed a molecular docking study using GOLD software. As reported previously,(42) the docking analysis of antagonist 1 reveals that the purine ring forms π–π stacking with two hydrophobic residues Phe327 and Tyr1374* (Figure 2A). Hydrogen-bonding interaction between the ethylpiperazine at the C–6 position of compound 1 and the hydroxyl group of Ser452 was found to be one of the crucial interactions signifying the importance of terminal nitrogen in the piperazine group as observed in the SAR development. Moreover, the N9 position of the alkyl linker attached to ethyl piperazine at the terminal is stabilized by the hydrophobic environment of Leu331 and Phe329. Significantly, in the energetically favorable docking pose, we had observed that the C2 position in compound 1 is flanked by hydrophobic residues such as Phe329 and Gly357. Thus, in the current study, the introduction of the hydrophilic −NH2 group at the C2 position in compound 5 leads to the flipping of the molecule (Figure 2B), resulting in loss of necessary interactions required for TLR7 antagonism. A similar docking result was observed for compound 6 as well. Substituting the C2 −NH2 with hydrophobic para-substituted benzylamine in compound 10 resulted in a similar conformation as that of compound 1 with the C2 substituent occupying the hydrophobic space (Figure 2C). This could be the probable reason for the similar TLR7 antagonism of compound 10 as that of compound 1.
    In our next set of SAR development, we extended the amine substitution at C2 further by introducing benzyl and para-substituted benzyl derivatives in compounds 7–10 (Scheme 1). It was observed that compound 7 with benzyl substitution showed better TLR7 and TLR9 antagonism (IC50 = 7.6 μM against TLR7 and IC50 = 0.14 μM against TLR9) compared to compound 5. The para-substituted benzyl derivatives (8–10) exhibited similar TLR9 inhibitory activity with 4-methoxybenzyl in compound 8 (IC50 = 0.20 μM), 4-fluorobenzyl in compound 9 (IC50 = 0.47 μM), and compound 10 (IC50 = 0.44 μM) with the N,N-diethylbenzyl group (Table 1). When tested for TLR7 antagonism,(49) compounds 8, 9, and 10 were found to show significant TLR7 inhibition with IC50 values of 5.22, 10.14, and 2.70 μM, respectively. To explore the C2 position further, we introduced a benzamide group in place of the benzyl group. This modification resulted in compound 11 with an IC50 value of 0.34 μM against TLR9 and 7.74 μM against TLR7. A comparison was drawn between compounds 7 and 11 because of their structural similarity. Compound 7 with benzylamine substitution at the C2 position was found to exhibit a slightly better TLR9 inhibition as compared to compound 11. Next, we capped the −NH2 group at C2 by reacting with 1,4-dibromobutane to form a pyrrolidine. This modification was found to be futile as the resulting compound 12 did not manifest in any improvement in the inhibitory profile (IC50 = 8.49 μM against TLR7 and IC50 = 0.50 μM against TLR9). Thus, Table 1 depicts that most of the compounds in this series are found to be dual inhibitors of TLR7 and TLR9.(50,51)
    Looking at the selectivity profile of the initial set of compounds, we observed that this set of compounds exhibited significant selectivity toward TLR9 against TLR7. It should also be mentioned that although compound 7 with benzylamine at the C2 position exhibited moderate TLR7 antagonism, yet it showed 54-fold selectivity for TLR9 as compared to TLR7 because of its excellent TLR9 antagonistic activity. This data prompted us to explore the selectivity aspect in the purine scaffold by keeping substituted benzylamine at the C2 position.
    Next, by keeping the −NH2 group at C2, we increased the hydrophobic bulk by introducing the cyclopentyl piperazine at the C6 position to afford intermediate 6, which moderately improved the TLR9 inhibition (IC50 = 0.279 μM) as compared to compound 5. Comparison of TLR7 inhibition among compounds 1, 5, and 6 revealed that the introduction of the −NH2 group at C2 markedly increased the selectivity between TLR7 and TLR9 antagonism. Therefore, similar substituents, as observed in the previous set of compounds, were introduced at C2 in compound 6 to obtain compounds 13, 14, and 15 with the 4-methoxybenzyl group, the 4-fluorobenzyl group, and the N,N-diethylbenzyl group, respectively (Scheme 1). To our satisfaction, these compounds showed better TLR9 inhibitory activity compared to their ethyl substituted counterparts at the C6 position in compounds 8, 9, and 10. Expectedly, compound 15 exhibited dual inhibition against TLR7 and TLR9 with a moderate IC50 value of 8.13 μM in TLR7 as compared to the inhibitory activity profile of its counterpart compound 10 with ethyl piperazine at C6. Interestingly, compound 16 with a methylene bridge at the para position in the 4-((dimethylamino)methyl)benzamide moiety manifested excellent TLR9 antagonism with an IC50 value of 0.056 μM and 130-fold selectivity against TLR7 (Table 1). Taking together all of the data from these studies, we could identify the nature of substituents at different positions in the purine scaffold that can modulate TLR9 and TLR7 inhibition and selectivity against TLR7.
    To look into the effect of the C6 position of the purine scaffold, we investigated the influence of piperazine substitution at C6 in our next series of compounds 18–26 (Scheme 2). We had observed that the C6 position plays an important role in regulating the activity. The replacement of the ethyl and cyclopentyl groups with small aromatic and aliphatic amides in the piperazine group at the C6 position resulted in a drastic decrease in both TLR9 and TLR7 inhibitory activities. All of the compounds in this series other than compounds 22 (IC50 = 3.4 μM against TLR9) and 26 (IC50 = 8.80 μM against TLR9) did not manifest any significant TLR9 inhibition at 30 μM. Moreover, both of them also exhibited promising TLR7 antagonism with IC50 values of 8.40 μM and 9.79 μM, respectively. Notably, both compounds 22 and 26 have diethylamino substituted benzylamines at C2 of the purine ring. It is worthwhile to mention that an amide group at the C2 position led to a significant increase in TLR9 antagonism as well as deriving moderate TLR7-targeted activity in compounds 11 and 16. On the other hand, amide substituents at the C6 position with the piperazine group resulted in a drastic reduction in both TLR9 and TLR7 antagonism. In summary, the SAR analysis so far reveals that aliphatic substitutions on the piperazine ring at the C6 position are well-tolerated, whereas compounds with electron-withdrawing functionality such as amides at this position do not show any significant inhibition at 30 μM. Different structural modifications revealed that compound 10 exhibited significant dual antagonism against both TLR9 and TLR7, whereas compound 16 was found to be the most potent TLR9 antagonist with 130-fold selectivity over TLR7 antagonism (Table 1).
    The TLR8 reporter assay of compound 16 was performed using HEK293 cells transfected with hTLR8 (mean ± SD, n = 3). The IC50 value was found to be >30 μM.
    Commercially available TLR agonists (CpGB for TLR9, CL264 for TLR7, and CL075 for TLR8) were used as positive controls.
    As endosomal TLRs are present inside acidic compartments, compounds with variable protonation centers can greatly influence the internalization and endosomal sequestration.(11,52) We have observed earlier that changing the substitution pattern at the three-carbon alkyl substitution at the N9 position can greatly influence the TLR7 antagonism.(42) As further optimization, we focused our attention on the N9 position by replacing the ethylpiperazine group with a less bulky pyrrolidine group. In the next step of SAR development (compounds 27–34, Scheme 3), we fixed the propylpyrrolidine linker at the N9 position while keeping favorable substituents at C2 and C6 positions, resulting in promising TLR9 and TLR7 antagonism. It is worthwhile to mention that compounds 27 and 28 with the propylpyrrolidine linker at the N9 position were the first set of compounds with the −NH2 group at C2 to show significant TLR7 antagonism with IC50 values of 4.94 μM and 4.88 μM, respectively (Table 2). On the other hand, compounds 5 and 6 having ethyl piperazine substitution at N9 showed lesser TLR7 inhibition (Table 1). The docking study of compound 27 provided an interesting insight into the binding nature of N9 substituents in the hydrophobic cavity (Figure 3A). It was found that due to the presence of a less bulky pyrrolidine group at the N9 position in compound 27, the compound can slightly reorganize itself in the hydrophobic cavity of the TLR7 active site (Figure 3B), retaining similar conformation as that of compound 1 with a root-mean-square-deviation (RMSD) value of 3.71 Å. This reorganization enables the amine group at C2 in compound 27 to be stabilized by hydrophilic amino acid residues such as Gln301, which is situated close to the hydrophobic zone as observed in Figures 2B and 3B. The N9 substituents fit into the hydrophobic pocket, and C6 ethyl piperazine attains hydrogen-bonding interaction with the important Ser452 residue (Figure 3A). It is worth mentioning that a similar docking experiment with a bulkier ethylpiperazine group having a flexible linker at N9 in compound 5 did not allow this reorganization in the active site of TLR7 and resulted in a completely flipped conformation. Comparing the TLR7 activities of compounds 5, 6, 27, and 28, we can state that the bulky nature of the substituents at C6 does not modulate the TLR7 inhibition, whereas the nature of N9 substituents plays an important role.
    Table 2. SAR Modification to the N9 Pyrrolidine Substituted Purine Scaffold
    a

    The IC50 values were derived from reporter assays using HEK293 cells transfected with hTLR9 (mean ± SD, n = 3).

    b

    The IC50 values were derived from reporter assays using HEK293 cells transfected with hTLR7 (mean ± SD, n = 3). TLR8 reporter assays of compound 29, 30, and 32 were performed using HEK293 cells transfected with hTLR8 (mean ± SD, n = 3). The IC50 value of all of them was found to be >30 μM. Commercially available TLR agonists (CpGB for TLR9, CL264 for TLR7, and CL075 for TLR8) were used as positive controls.

    To continue the study further, we kept the same two types of substitutions at the C2 position like in the previous set of compounds such as the 4-methoxybenzyl group in 29 and 31 and the 4-fluorobenzyl group in 30 and 32 (Scheme 3). To our satisfaction, all of these compounds were found to manifest excellent TLR9 antagonism with compound 29 being a dual TLR7/9 antagonist and compound 30 having maximum TLR9 inhibition (IC50 = 0.036 μM) as well as significant selectivity against TLR7. In comparison to its counterparts having an ethyl piperazine group at the N9 position (compounds 8, 9 and 13, 14), compounds 29–32 with the pyrrolidine group at N9 exhibited better TLR9 inhibition with higher selectivity against TLR7 (Table 2, Figure 4).
    In our previous series (Table 1), compound 16 with the ((dimethylamino)methyl)benzamide moiety at the C2 position showed excellent TLR9 inhibition (IC50 = 0.056 μM). As a logical extension, we incorporated similar substituents at C2 in compounds 33 and 34 keeping the propylpyrrolidine group at the N9 position (Scheme 3, Figure 4). Both compounds showed very potent TLR9 inhibition with more than 200-fold selectivity against TLR7 antagonism. Compound 34 showed the best TLR9 inhibition among all of the compounds with an IC50 value of 0.007 μM and that of 9.25 μM against TLR7. Notably, all three compounds 16, 33, and 34 with the ((dimethylamino)methyl)benzamide moiety at the C2 position of the purine scaffold showed the most potent TLR9 antagonism among all of the compounds (Table 2).
    TLR8 reporter assays of compounds 29, 30, and 32 were performed using HEK293 cells transfected with hTLR8 (mean ± SD, n = 3). The IC50 values of all of them were found to be >30 μM.
    Commercially available TLR agonists (CpGB for TLR9, CL264 for TLR7, and CL075 for TLR8) were used as positive controls.

    Selectivity of Antagonists against TLR8

    The crystal structure of monkey TLR7 (PDB: 5GMF) revealed two distinct binding sites.(53) Small-molecule ligands bind to the first site (binding site 1), whereas truncated polyU only binds to the second site (binding site 2).(54) The proposed antagonistic binding site 1 of TLR7 consists of LRR11–13 on one side and LRR15*-16* on another side of the homodimeric ectodomain. It is observed that the active site domain of binding site 1 of human TLR7 consisting of His 276, Phe327, Phe329, Leu331, Ser452, Glu1248*, and Tyr1374* is not aligned with the corresponding amino acid residues of monkey TLR7 (Figures S5 and S6). The crystal structure of human TLR8 (PDB ID: 5WYZ) was chosen as the template for building the human TLR7 homology model as the homodimeric chains of both structures are aligned with each other (Figure S7A).(55,56) Although the conserved antagonist binding domains (binding site 1) of TLR7 and TLR8 reside nearby, the structural and sequential alignment revealed that some of the antagonistic binding residues, such as polar Thr384 of TLR7, are not similar to that of the human TLR8. Polar residue Thr384 in TLR7 is replaced with nonpolar bulky Ile403 in TLR8.(42) Additionally, Ser452 and Glu459 are also not able to align with any comparable amino acids from TLR8 ectodomains (Figure S7B). It can be perceived that this difference in the nature of the amino acids plays a pivotal role in imparting selective antagonistic activity between TLR7 and TLR8. Docking of our lead antagonists (compounds 29 and 30) in the homology model of the homodimerized TLR7 ectodomain manifests in conserved hydrogen bonding with Ser452 and the important π–π interaction with Tyr1374* (Figure 5A,B). However, docking of these two antagonists with the TLR8 ectodomain does not exhibit similar interactions due to a change in binding conformation. This could be the plausible explanation for the selectivity of these antagonists against the TLR8 protein.

    Isothermal Titration Calorimetry (ITC) Experiment

    Exclusion of direct interaction of compound 29/30 with TLR9/7 agonists CpGB/CL264 by isothermal titration calorimetry (ITC) was used to indirectly establish the binding of compounds 29 and 30 to human TLR7/TLR9. The titration of both antagonists 29 and 30 into CpGB (commercially available TLR9 agonist) did not yield sufficient changes in heat signals, indicating that there is negligible interaction between both antagonists and CpGB (Figure S8A,C). Additionally, we assessed the binding capacities of these two antagonists with CL264 (commercially available TLR7 agonist). The heat signals obtained during the titration of the antagonists into CL264 (Figure S8B,D) exhibited results similar to those obtained for CpGB. Hence, we were able to conclusively rule out any role of compound–agonist binding as the reason behind the observed antagonistic activity of the compounds. Furthermore, by logical extrapolation of these findings, we can conclude that the TLR7/9 antagonism shown by the antagonists is most likely the result of the interaction between the antagonists with the respective TLR protein.

    In Vitro ADME Study

    The in vitro pharmacokinetic properties of five of the most potent TLR9 antagonists (29, 30, 32, 33, and 34) were evaluated in a panel of in vitro ADME assays (Tables 3–5).(57,58) All of these compounds having structural similarity at N9 with variation at the C6-piperazine and para position of the C2 phenyl ring were assessed through a series of established assays, providing us insights into how in vitro pharmacokinetic properties are affected by structural modifications in the scaffold. We initiated ADME profile inspection with the in silico calculation of some key physicochemical properties such as polar surface area and clogP (Table 3). We investigated kinetic solubility at pH 7.4, plasma (human and mouse) stability, microsomal (human and mouse) stability, and Caco-2 permeability through a series of established in vitro assays.(59,60) The aqueous solubility of all of the compounds was found to range from moderate to excellent. To our satisfaction, all of the selected compounds exhibited significant Caco-2 cell permeability with an efflux ratio of less than 2, suggesting that these molecules are not substrates of P-gp (P-glycoprotein) and are expected to be absorbed well in the gastrointestinal tract. However, out of the five compounds, compounds 29 and 30 demonstrated the highest human plasma stability at 2 h. In the human and mouse microsomal stability assay, compound 29 showed T1/2 values of 60 and 48 min, respectively. In contrast, compound 30 had moderate human microsomal stability and 4 times half-life variation in human and mouse metabolic stability. Although compound 33 has promising metabolic stability, its poor plasma stability in mouse made it a weak contender in selection for in vivo studies. Although compound 34 showed the lowest IC50 value (5.0 nM) against TLR9, it was not considered for further study due to poor plasma stability in both mice and humans. Considering all of the above parameters, we finally decided to carry forward in vivo studies with compound 29 as all of the in vitro pharmacokinetic parameters of this compound are in the ideal range. In the next study, we have explored the in vivo pharmacokinetic profile of compound 29.
    Table 3. In Vitro Pharmacokinetic Profile of Potent Compounds

    In Vivo Pharmacokinetic Study

    Finally, to evaluate the in vivo applicability of the potent TLR9 antagonist 29, we performed the in vivo pharmacokinetics of the compound by administering 10 mg/kg through both the oral route and the intravenous route of administration in C57BL/6 mice (Table 6). The compound was found to be rapidly absorbed into the blood with a half-life of 3.4 h upon oral administration. It was also found that the maximum plasma concentration (Cmax) surpassed the in vitro IC50 against TLR9 at 10 mg/kg oral dose. The volume of distribution (Vss) of compound 29 was assessed at 14.1 L/kg, which is consistent with the basic nature of the compound. Moreover, average aqueous solubility (49.4 μg/mL at pH = 7.4) and good lipophilicity of the compound also contribute to its high volume of distribution. All of these in vitro and in vivo pharmacokinetic parameters of compound 29 sum up to provide moderate oral bioavailability (F = 38%).
    Table 6. In Vivo Pharmacokinetic Parameters of Compound 29
    dose (mg/kg)route of administrationaCmax (ng/mL)tmax (h)t1/2 (h)AUC0–24h (ng h/mL)CL (mL/min kg)Vss (L/kg)F (%)
    10 (n = 3)iv  0.76780.2213.614.138
    10 (n = 3)po62.323.4296.3   
    a

    Compounds were administered at 10 mg/kg in mice (n = 3). Here, Cmax is the maximum concentration of drug in plasma/blood, tmax is the time required to reach Cmax, t1/2 is the half-life, AUC is the area under the curve, CL is the rate of clearance, and Vss is the volume of distribution.

    In Vitro Cellular Toxicity Assay

    From our library, we selected six hit compounds 16, 29, 30, 32, 33, and 34 for cytotoxicity assessment. We checked the in vitro toxicity in various cell lines of different tissue origins such as human peripheral blood mononuclear cells (hematopoietic origin), HCT116 (a colon cancer cell line representing the gut epithelium of an endodermal origin), HepG2 (a hepatocellular carcinoma cell line representing hepatocytes of a mesodermal origin), and H9C2 (a rat cardiomyoblast cell line representing a mesodermal origin) by propidium iodide staining. To our satisfaction, none of our hit molecules showed appreciable toxicity in the above-mentioned cell lines up to 20 μM concentration of the compounds (Figure 6A–D).

    In Vivo TLR9 Antagonism Efficacy

    Aberrant TLR9 activation in tissue-recruited pDCs, caused by the buildup of abundant self-DNA in a confined space, leads to excessive type I IFN induction, which plays a crucial pathogenetic role in clinical contexts of autoimmune diseases. Expressions of interferon signature genes (ISGs) in tissues are reliable biomarkers of IFN signaling and are associated with disease activity in clinical contexts.(55) These also serve as reliable surrogates for assessing local induction of type I IFNs. To estimate the in vivo efficacy of a representative TLR9 antagonist 29, we used a clinically relevant murine model reported in one of our previous studies (Figure 7A).(39) We administered a mixture of CpGA and CpGB, the bona fide TLR9 ligand, to the peritoneal cavity of C57BL/6 mice, which caused immune cell (including pDC) infiltration into the peritoneum (Figure 7B), followed by IFNα induction. To analyze and compare the local induction of type I IFNs in the peritoneum of mice fed or not fed with compound 29, we directly quantified the protein concentration of IFNα in the peritoneal fluid (Figure 7C) and also evaluated the mRNA expressions of two interferon signature genes (reliable biomarkers of IFN signaling, associated with disease activity in clinical contexts), IFIT1 and ISG15, in the cells recovered from the inflamed peritoneal cavity (Figure 7D,E). The significant depletion of the type I IFN protein in the peritoneal fluid, as well as the mRNA expression levels of both ISGs, established the in vivo efficacy of our potent antagonist 29.

    In Vivo Therapeutic Efficacy Study

    To study the efficacy of compound 29 as a dual TLR7/9 antagonist in the context of a TLR7/9-mediated autoimmune disease in vivo, we used a preclinical model of murine psoriasis. This model bears a strong resemblance to human psoriasis(61) and has been used in multiple studies to explore the pathogenesis of the disease.(62) The model was developed as previously reported(42) and displayed all morphological features associated with psoriasiform inflammation (Figure 8A). Daily oral administration of the compound led to drastic ablation of psoriasis-like cutaneous morphology (Figure 8A). Moreover, histopathologic exploration of psoriatic skin sections from control and treated mice revealed stark differences, with treated skin resembling normal skin to a greater extent (Figure 8B). A scoring system of each pathognomonic feature such as hyperkeratosis, parakeratosis, acanthosis, papillomatosis, suprapapilary thinning, and vascular dilatation with the highest severity given a score of 3 and least severity given a score of 1 (Figure 8C) indicated a significant reduction in disease severity in response to treatment with compound (Figure 8D,E). Thus, the ability of compound 29 to significantly reduce disease severity of a TLR7/9-driven autoimmune disease in vivo could be established similarly.

    Short-Term Visceral Toxicity Assessment

    Histomorphological evaluation of murine lung, liver, and kidney specimens was done to rule out any deleterious impact of compound 29 on these major organs. Hematoxylin and eosin-stained sections of the liver, lung, and kidney did not show any major morphologic changes upon oral administration of 20 mg of compound 29 per kg body weight of mice (Figure 9B,D,F) for 7 consecutive days in comparison to mice treated only with vehicle (Figure 9A,C,E). Morphology of hepatocytes was normal in liver sections of both vehicle-treated (Figure 9A) and compound-treated (Figure 9B) mice. The absence of microvesicular steatosis, as well as lack of inflammatory cell aggregation, indicated a lack of short-term toxicity of compound 29 on the murine liver. Similarly, no major inflammatory cell infiltration was observed in any of the murine lung sections, and the alveolar sac histologies of both vehicle-treated (Figure 9C) and compound-treated (Figure 9D) mice were comparable. Finally, examination of kidney sections revealed normal morphology of glomerular and tubular structures, as well as the mesangial cells in compound-treated mice (Figure 9F), and no observable difference could be seen with that of the control group (Figure 9E). At the same time, no behavioral or physiological changes were observed in any of the animals during the experimental period. Postmortem observations also did not reveal any macroscopic abnormalities in any of the animals. All of these observations cumulatively indicated the lack of short-term toxicity of compound 29 following oral administration for 7 consecutive days in C57BL/6 mice.

    Conclusions

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    In the present study, we have reported strategies for the systematic development of potent dual TLR7/9 antagonists as well as factors modulating selective TLR9 antagonism. The SAR analysis revealed that there exist concerted relationships between the nature of substituents at C2, C6, and N9 positions. Various substituents with suitable basicity and lipophilicity at C2, C6, and N9 of the purine ring have shown potent TLR9 antagonism with IC50 < 100 nM and high selectivity against TLR7 (Tables 1 and 2). At the C2 position, suitable substitutions such as −NH2, substituted benzylamines, and benzamides are well-tolerated for TLR9 inhibition. On the other hand, when −NH2 substitution is present at the C2 position, suitable N9 substituents can modulate TLR7 inhibition. At the C6 position, piperazine with hydrophobic ethyl and cyclopentyl groups are favorable as compared to electron-withdrawing amides. At N9, both ethyl piperazine and pyrrolidine groups can manifest promising TLR9 antagonism with high selectivity against TLR7. The selection of compound 29 as the lead (from among the set of hit compounds obtained from reporter assays) was done based on various in vitro pharmacokinetic assays. In an alternative approach, ITC experiments could rule out possible antagonism caused by binding of target compounds directly to the TLR ligands, thus indicating that the antagonism manifested by the lead candidates 29 and 30 is the result of the interaction between the antagonists and the respective TLR protein. Notably, compound 29 did not exhibit any significant TLR8 inhibition up to 30 μM (Supporting Information, Figure S3). The lead compound 29 showed moderate aqueous solubility at pH 7.4, good Caco-2 permeability, as well as excellent plasma and microsomal stability in both mice and human. The in vivo pharmacokinetic parameters of this compound in mice revealed 38% oral bioavailability. In the in vivo efficacy model, compound 29 was found to be efficacious (at a considerably low dose of 10 mg/kg body weight) in inhibiting TLR9 activation as measured by its ability to efficiently suppress the TLR9-mediated type I IFN response. Finally, the in vivo therapeutic efficacy of the lead compound 29 was established in a preclinical murine model of psoriasis. Histomorphological evaluation of the lung, liver, and kidney did not show any major morphologic changes following oral administration of compound 29. These results provide compelling evidence, which advocates compound 29 as a potential candidate for future development into a clinically relevant therapeutic molecule. The systematic SAR analysis described in the manuscript can be regarded as a benchmark to develop potent TLR7 and TLR9 antagonists in various scaffolds in the future.

    Experimental Section

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Aqueous Solubility Assay

    A total of 5 μL of 20 mM dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) stock solution was added to the reaction deep well plate containing 495 μL of pH 7.4 pION buffer, including the DMSO control. The samples were mixed and incubated for 18 h. The plate was sealed well during the incubation process. The DMSO content in the sample was <1.0%. The deep well plate contained solution having a concentration of 200 μM. Then, 4 μL of 20 mM stock (including the DMSO control) to 996 μL of acetonitrile was added to prepare a working stock plate. A total of 75 μL of the working stock was added to 75 μL of the blank buffer and read on a spectrophotometer with a reference plate at 240 nm. A filter plate was used to vacuum-filter 100 μL of the sample from the storage plate after the incubation period was completed. The filtrate was discarded when filters became completely wet. A new filter collection plate was taken, and another 200 μL of the sample from a deep well plate was vacuum-filtered into it. The filtrate (75 μL) from the filter collection plate was transferred to a UV sample plate. Acetonitrile (75 μL) was added to this UV plate and mixed properly, and the spectrum was read using the UV spectrophotometer at 240 nm. Plates were read on spectramax using SoftMax Pro software version 5.3.

    Caco-2 Permeability Assay

    A total of 10 mM stock of the compound in DMSO was diluted with Hank’s balanced salt solution (HBSS) buffer at pH 7.4 to a final concentration of 10 μM. To proliferate the cells, 250 μL of Dulbecco’s modified Eagle’s medium (DMEM) was added to the basal compartment of a 96-well multiscreen Caco-2 plate and seeded at 12 000 cells/well (0.16 × 106 cells/mL) in all of the apical wells, which were placed in a CO2 incubator at 37 °C. On the day of the experiment, the medium was taken out and washed twice with HBSS buffer. A total of 250 μL of the buffer with 2% bovine serum albumin (BSA) was added to basal wells, and 75 μL of the test compound was added to apical wells. Then, 25 μL of basal samples was collected at 120 min and processed as follows. A total of 250 μL of the test compound and 75 μL of HBSS buffer with 2% BSA were added to basal wells and apical wells, respectively. At 120 min, apical samples (25 μL) were collected and processed as mentioned below. A single-point calibration curve in the buffer with 2% BSA was used. Donor and receiver samples were diluted 1:1 with the buffer separately, while the former contains 2% BSA. It was precipitated with 200 μL of acetonitrile containing an internal standard and vortexed for 5 min at 1000 rpm and then further centrifuged at 4000 rpm for 10 min. Finally, 100 μL of the supernatant was diluted with 200 μL of water and analyzed in liquid chromatography–mass spectrometry (LC–MS)/MS analysis.

    Plasma Stability Assay

    A total of 10 mM stock solution in DMSO was prepared and stored at 4 °C. Then, 25 μM stock solution of the test compound was prepared in ACN/water by diluting the previously prepared 10 mM stock, i.e., 2.5 μL of the 10 mM stock solution was added to 997.5 μL of acetonitrile/water (50:50). The frozen plasma was thawed at room temperature and centrifuged at 1400× relative centrifugal force (RCF) at 4 °C for 15 min. Approximately 90% of the clear supernatant fraction was transferred to a separate tube and was then used for the experiment. For 0 min samples, plasma was heat-inactivated at 56 °C for 45 min. Then, 3 μL of the 25 μM test compound was added to 72 μL of heat-inactivated plasma. An aliquot of 25 μL of the mixture was taken and crashed with 200 μL of acetonitrile containing the internal standard and further processed along with other time points. A final working stock solution of 1 μM was prepared by diluting samples in plasma for other time points (i.e., 8 μL of 25 μM acetonitrile/water stock was added to 192 μL of plasma). A total of 200 μL of plasma containing the test compound was incubated for 2 h at 37 °C in a shaker water bath with gentle shaking. An aliquot of 25 μL of the sample at 0, 15, 30, 60, and 120 min was precipitated immediately with 200 μL of acetonitrile containing the internal standard and centrifuged at 4000× RCF, 4 °C for 20 min. Then, 150 μL of the supernatant was diluted with 150 μL of water and analyzed on liquid chromatography–mass spectrometry (LC–MS)/MS.

    Microsomal Stability Assay

    A total of 10 mM stock solution of the test compound in DMSO was diluted with 1:1 water and acetonitrile to afford a 200 μL of 1 mM stock solution. Then, 100 μM working concentration of the test compound was prepared by diluting 1 mM stock solution of the test compound in DMSO with ACN/water (1:1). Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate (NADPH) cofactor solution (2.5 mM) was prepared from a 16 mM stock solution, and a 3.33 mg/mL working stock of liver microsomes was prepared from a 20 mg/mL liver microsome master stock solution. A total of 85 μL of phosphate buffer of pH 7.4 was mixed with 2.5 μL of the 100 μM test compound and 75 μL of 3.33 mg/mL HLM in a deep well plate for preincubation of 10 min at 37 °C. Then, 32.5 μL of the mixture was added to 17.5 μL of buffer and incubated for 60 min without the NADPH cofactor. For the 0 min sample, 16.5 μL of the preincubated mixture was crashed with 200 μL of acetonitrile and 8.75 μL of cofactor was added to it. After this, 62 μL of the NADPH cofactor was added to the remaining incubation mixture and kept for 60 min at 37 °C. For other time point samples, 25 μL of the incubation mixture at 5, 10, 30, 60, and 60 min without the cofactor was precipitated immediately with 200 μL of acetonitrile containing the internal standard and vortexed for 5 min at 1200 rpm. The samples were centrifuged at 4000× RCF at 4 °C for 10 min. The supernatant (150 μL) was diluted with 150 μL of water and processed on LC–MS/MS.

    Isothermal Titration Calorimetry

    ITC experiments were performed in a buffer composed of 25 mM 4-morpholineethansulfonic acid (MES) pH 5.5, 0.20 M NaCl, and 1% DMSO at 298 K using a MicroCal iTC200 (GE Healthcare). The titration sequence included a single 0.4 μL injection followed by 20 injections, 2 μL each, with a spacing of 120 s between the injections. The titration conditions were as follows: 100 μM compound 29 into 10 μM CpGB; 100 μM compound 29 into 10 μM CL264. OriginLab software (GE Healthcare) was used to analyze the raw ITC data.

    Reporter Assay to Measure TLR9, TLR7, and TLR8 Antagonism

    To monitor the antagonistic efficacy of the synthesized compounds against TLR9, TLR7, and TLR8, HEK-BlueTLR9, HEK-BlueTLR7, and HEK-BlueTLR8 reporter cell lines (Invivogen) were used, respectively. The principle behind the assay involves TLR agonist/antagonist-mediated NF-κB activation/inhibition, which in turn causes/inhibits SEAP production, secretion into the culture supernatant, and color change of the detection media—ultimately indicating whether TLR activation is successful or not. Approximately 70 000 cells were seeded in complete DMEM media and incubated for 5 h at 37 °C and 5% CO2 before indicated concentrations of mentioned compounds were added to the wells. After 1 h of compound addition, indicated doses of commercially available TLR agonists (CpGB for TLR9, CL264 for TLR7, and CL075 for TLR8—Invivogen), used as positive controls and against which the inhibitory activity of the compounds was tested, were added in the required wells. Cells were incubated overnight, and on the next day, the culture supernatant was added to Quanti-Blue detection media and once again incubated with periodic monitoring for color changes. Upon color change, spectrophotometric reading of the OD value at 650 nm wavelength was recorded.

    TLR9 Antagonism Assay in Human PBMCs

    Blood was drawn from healthy donors after obtaining informed consent as well as approval from the institutional ethics board. PBMCs were isolated from the blood using density gradient centrifugation. A total of 200 000 PBMCs/well were cultured and treated with indicated doses of compounds for 1 h before CpGA (TLR9 agonist—Invivogen) was added for overnight incubation. The next day, the culture supernatants were collected and subjected to IFNα ELISA according to the manufacturer’s protocol (Mabtech, Sweden).

    Molecular Docking Study

    Ligand Preparation

    The two-dimensional (2D) form of the structurally diverse purine class of the TLR7/9 antagonist molecules was drawn on ChemDraw Ultra and converted to their three-dimensional (3D) structures by Accelrys Discovery Studio 4.1 (DS). All of the compounds were energy-minimized by performing 2000 steps of steepest descent followed by conjugate gradient algorithms, which conserved the RMSD gradient of 0.01 Å.(63) All of the compounds were processed at pH 5.5–6.5.

    Protein Preparation

    The human TLR7 ectodomain 3D structure used in the docking calculation was solved by homology building using the template hTLR8 crystal structure by the Discovery Studio MODELER suite. The human TLR8 ectodomain crystal structure (PDB ID: 5WYZ) was extracted out from the protein data bank (PDB). The co-crystallized water and heteroatoms were removed. The protein was prepared by maintaining the protonation state at pH 5.5–6.5 using the CHARMm force field.

    Molecular Docking

    Molecular docking of the designed compounds was accomplished on the hTLR7 using the GOLD2020.1 suite. Molecules were docked on the pre-described active site(42) on the homodimeric interface with a 6 Å radius sphere by selecting the active site residues of the protein. The default Genetic Algorithm module was implemented during the docking program for exploring probable ligand conformational flexibility and rotational flexibilities of the receptor hydrogen for hydrogen bonding into the binding sites.(64,65) In GOLD, docking was accomplished using a chemscore_kinase template with the ligand having 100% search efficiency, which indicates a ligand with five rotatable bonds having around 30000 GA operations.(66) “Early termination” was turned off, which specifies that the GOLD program will not be ended until it completes all of the GA operations. A cluster of 40 solutions was saved for each ligand having an RMSD cutoff of 1.7 Å. The GOLD docking program was used by GoldScore and ChemScore fitness function. GoldScore is a molecular mechanistic function that is specialized for the spatial binding of the ligand. The scoring function considers van der Waals energy, H-bonding energy, torsional strain, and potential metal interaction for the proper estimation of the ligand-binding conformation.(67)
    Molecular docking of the best active compound 29 was performed on the active site of the hTLR8 crystal structure. Molecules were docked on the co-crystallized antagonist binding site(68) in between the homodimeric interface with a grid size of 7.4 Å radius sphere around the active site residues of the protein. The default genetic algorithm was implemented during the docking program for allowing the probable ligand conformational and rotational flexibilities, which leads to the formation of hydrogen bonding with the binding site residues by following the CHARMm force field.(64) Probable binding conformation of the selected ligand was chosen among the cluster of 20 conformations.

    Cytotoxicity Assay in PBMCs

    The cytotoxic effects of indicated compounds were assayed in primary PBMCs. PBMCs were isolated from the blood of healthy donors after obtaining informed consent, using density gradient centrifugation. PBMCs (2 × 105) resuspended in complete RPMI medium were treated with 1, 5, 10, and 20 mM of the compounds overnight. Next morning, cells were harvested, resuspended in fresh phosphate-buffered saline (PBS), and stained by the addition of 2.5 μg/mL propidium iodide for 1 min before acquisition in a flow cytometer. Around 25% of DMSO was used as a positive control. The abundance of PI positive cells indicated the number of dead cells.

    Cytotoxicity Assay in HepG2, HCT116, and H9C2 Cell Lines

    The cytotoxicity of the compounds was assayed against HepG2 liver cancer cells of epithelial origin, H9C2 rat cardiomyocytes, and HCT116 colorectal cancer cells. A total of 6 × 104 cancer cells were incubated overnight in complete DMEM medium at 37 °C and 5% CO2. Next morning, 1, 5, 10, and 20 mM of the indicated compounds were added and incubated overnight once again, following which cells were harvested by gentle trypsinization, resuspended in fresh PBS, and stained by the addition of 2.5 mg/mL propidium iodide 1 min before acquisition in a flow cytometer. The PI positive population of cells provides a measure of dying cells. Around 25% of DMSO was used as a positive control.

    In Vivo Pharmacokinetic Experiment

    Eight 8–10 weeks old male C57BL/6 mice were taken for the in vivo pharmacokinetic experiment. They were divided into two groups each having four mice. Compound 29 was reconstituted in 2% ethanol in PBS (0.01 M, pH = 7.4). The mice of the first group were orally administered compound 29 at 10 mg/kg dose, and the mice belonging to the second group were given intravenous injections of 10 mg/kg compound. Blood samples were collected at 0, 0.5, 1, 2, 4, 6, 12, and 24 h after oral administration of the compound, and serum was isolated with the compound. On the other hand, blood samples were drawn at 0, 0.25, 0.5, 1, 2, 4, 6, 12, and 24 h after intravenous administration of the compound and serum was isolated. For the pharmacokinetic study, 10 μL of serum samples from mice was extracted with 40 μL of LC/MS-grade acetonitrile + 0.1% formic acid (1:5 dilution) and incubated on ice for 15 min with intermittent vortexing and then centrifuged at 14 000 rpm for 10 min. Thereafter, the supernatant was collected and analyzed by LC–MS/MS to measure the concentration of compound 29 in the serum. Standards of the compound ranging from 24.784 to 2794 pg were prepared in the serum and extracted in acetonitrile + 0.1% formic acid in the same way. Mass spectrometry was performed in LTQ ORBITRAP XL using the Hypersil Gold C18 column having a diameter of 100 × 2.1 mm2 with a particle size of 1.9 μm. The column formed the stationary phase, and a mixture of solution A (acetonitrile + 0.1% formic acid) and solution B (HPLC-grade H2O + 0.1% formic acid) formed the mobile phase. Liquid chromatography (injection volume 5 μL) was performed using an isocratic solution containing 40% acetonitrile and 0.1% formic acid. The intact compound had a retention time of 0.75 min and (m/z) of 479.3195, while (m/z) of the fragmented compound after MS/MS was 408.2512. All data were analyzed using Thermo Xcalibur software.

    In Vivo Inhibition Assay

    In vivo studies in mice were performed after obtaining approval from the Animal Ethics Committee of CSIR-IICB. For the in vivo efficacy assay, 6–8 weeks old female C57BL/6 mice were recruited and divided into three groups. There were 4–5 mice in each of the three groups. The first group was given intraperitoneal injections of PBS (vehicle). The second group was injected IP with mouse 25 μg of CpGA + 25 μg of mouse CpGB. The third group members were orally administered with 10 mg/kg of the compound 1 h before IP injection with the CpGA/CpGB mixture. The mice were left overnight, and the next day all of the mice were sacrificed and the peritoneal fluid along with intraperitoneal cells was collected. The peritoneal fluid was subjected to IFNα ELISA, while the peritoneal cells were subjected to gene expression studies.

    Mouse IFNα ELISA

    The concentration of IFNα in mouse peritoneal fluid was estimated by sandwich ELISA. For this, 1:1000 times diluted RMMA-1 primary antibody from the pbl interferon source was used, before the addition of peritoneal fluid samples and incubation for 2 h. The secondary antibody used in this case for detection was 1:500 times diluted polyclonal rabbit IgG antibody detecting mouse IFNα. Once again after incubation and washing 1:10 000 times diluted tertiary antibody (horseradish peroxidase (HRP) conjugated antirabbit IgG) was added. In the final step, detection was done using the TMB substrate and OD values were measured as described above.

    Quantitative PCR

    Total RNA was isolated from peritoneal cells according to the TRIzol (Invitrogen) method and reverse-transcribed into cDNA (High-Capacity cDNA Reverse Transcription Kit, Applied Bisosystems). qPCR was performed in a Quant-studio 3 PCR machine using BioRadSyBR Green to monitor the expression of the indicated genes: MuISG15 (forward primer: ACGGTCTTACCCTTTCCAGTC; reverse primer: CCCCTTTCGTTCCTCACCAG), MuIFIT (forward primer: AGGCTGGAGTGTGCTGAGAT; reverse primer: TCTGGATTTAACCGGACAGC), and Mu18S (forward primer: GTTGGTTTTCGGAACTGAGG; reverse primer: TCGTTTATGGTCGGAACTACG, housekeeping gene).

    Flow Cytometry

    Antimouse CD45 PE, TCRb APC-Cy7, Bst2 APC, and SiglecH BV421 fluorophore conjugated antibodies were used to stain peritoneal cells followed by acquisition in a BD Fortessa flow cytometer to determine the presence of pDCs in peritoneal infiltrates. FlowJo software Version 10 was used for the analysis.

    In Vivo Efficacy Study

    Thirteen wild-type C57BL/6 male mice aged 8–10 weeks, provided by the CSIR-IICB animal house facility, were divided into two groups: (1) the control group containing seven mice with induced psoriasis, treated with 2% ethanol in sterile PBS (0.01 M, pH = 7.4) (vehicle); and (2) the treatment group containing six mice with induced psoriasis treated with compound 29. Psoriasis was induced by daily topical application of 62.5 mg of 5% w/w imiquimod cream (Imiquad; Glenmark, India) on a patch of shaved dorsal skin of the mice for 6 consecutive days. Vehicle and compound (20 mg/kg) were administered orally daily for 7 days, beginning 1 day prior to the start of imiquimod application. The experimental animals were sacrificed on the 7th day of imiquimod application, and portions of affected skin were collected from each animal (in 4% paraformaldehyde) for histopathological evaluation by hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) staining. All animal handling and mouse experiments were conducted in accordance with national and international guidelines and upon approval from the institutional ethics committee. All recommendations enlisted in the ACS Ethical Guidelines were followed while performing the mouse experiments.

    Short-Term Toxicity Evaluation

    Short-term toxicity evaluation was performed by comparing histomorphological features of visceral organ specimens obtained from vehicle-treated and compound-treated mice. Lung, liver, and kidney specimens were harvested and preserved in 10% formalin on day 7, following oral administration of 20 mg/kg body weight of compound 29 or vehicle for 7 consecutive days. Histomorphological evaluation was done after H&E staining of the tissue sections. A Magnus MLXi Plus pathology microscope (objective magnification 10×) was used for image acquisition.

    Chemical Synthesis and Methods: General Methods

    All starting materials, reagents, and solvents were purchased from commercial suppliers and used without further purification. Air-sensitive reactions were carried out under dry nitrogen or argon atmosphere. For thin-layer chromatography (TLC), silica gel plates (Merck silica gel 60, F254) were used. RediSepRf silica gel columns were used for column chromatographic purification on the Teledyne ISCO CombiFlash Rf system using 230–400 mesh silica gel. 1H NMR was recorded at 300 MHz (Bruker-DPX), 400 MHz (Jeol), and 600 MHz (Bruker-Avance) frequencies and 13C NMR spectra were recorded at 75 MHz (Bruker-DPX), 100 MHz (Jeol), and 150 MHz (Bruker-Avance) frequencies using tetramethylsilane (TMS) as the internal standard. High-resolution mass spectra, HRMS (m/z), were measured using EI (Jeol-JMS 700 mass spectrometer), ESI (Q-Tof Micro mass spectrometer), and ESI (LTQ Orbitrap XL mass spectrometer) techniques. The purity of all of the compounds was determined to be >95%, analyzed by Hitachi HPLC using column Xtimate C18 (4.6 mm × 150 mm, 5.0 μm) using gradient elution of acetonitrile in water 0–90% for 12 min and flow rate 1 mL/min with detection at 254 nm wavelength.

    General Procedure A: Reductive Amination

    Appropriate amine (1.0 equiv) and aromatic aldehyde (1.2 equiv) were dissolved in toluene in the presence of molecular sieves (3A powder). The reaction mixture was refluxed at 110 °C under a N2 atmosphere for 12 h. Toluene was evaporated, and to it, dichloroethane (DCE) and sodium triacetoxyborohydride (2 equiv) were added. The reaction was stirred at room temperature for 2 h. The reaction mixture was neutralized with NaHCO3 solution and extracted with a CHCl3 system. Column chromatography was performed using the CHCl3/CH3OH system to obtain the pure product.

    General Procedure B: Amidation Using POCl3

    A mixture of appropriate amine (1.0 equiv) and 4-((dimethylamino)methyl)benzoic acid (1.2 equiv) was dissolved in dry pyridine (5 mL). POCl3 (1.5 equiv) was added to the solution at 0 °C, and the reaction mixture was stirred for 2 h. The reaction mixture was poured into crushed ice and neutralized with saturated Na2CO3 solution. The aqueous layer was extracted with chloroform, dried over Na2SO4, and evaporated under vacuum. The residue was purified by silica gel column chromatography to give the pure product.

    Synthesis of 6-(4-Ethylpiperazine-1-yl)-9H-purin-2-amine (3)

    1-Ethyl piperazine (1.12 mL, 8.84 mmol) was added to a stirred suspension of 6-chloro-9H-purin-2-amine 2 (1.0 g, 5.89 mmol) and potassium carbonate (1.63 g, 11.78 mmol) in dry acetonitrile. The mixture was refluxed for 4 h. Acetonitrile was removed under vacuum. The residue was washed with water, followed by filtration, and dried to obtain compound 3 as an off-white solid (89.6%, mp 230 °C). 1H NMR (300 MHz, CD3OD): δ 7.69 (s, 1H), 4.23–4.19 (m, 4H), 2.58 (t, J = 4.8 Hz, 4H), 2.49 (q, J = 7.2 Hz, 2H), 1.16 (t, J = 7.2 Hz, 3H). 13C NMR (75 MHz, CD3OD): δ 159.8, 154.2, 153.1, 135.3, 113.3, 52.5, 52.0, 44.3, 10.5. HRMS (ESI) m/z (M + H) calcd for C11H18N7, 248.1618; found, 248.1622.

    Synthesis of 6-(4-Cyclopentylpiperazin-1-yl)-9H-purin-2-amine (4)

    Compound 2 (1.0 g, 5.89 mmol) was dissolved in acetonitrile (8 mL), and potassium carbonate (1.63 g, 11.78 mmol) and 1-cyclopentylpiperazine (1.38 mL, 8.84 mmol) were added. The reaction mixture was refluxed for 6 h. The organic layer was extracted with the CHCl3 system and column chromatography was performed using the CH3OH and CHCl3 system to give compound 4 as a white solid (78%, mp > 250 °C). 1H NMR (300 MHz, DMSO-d6): δ 12.2 (br. s, −NH), 7.66 (s, 1H), 5.72 (s, −NH2), 4.09 (m, 4H), 2.46 (t, J = 4.2 Hz, 4H), 2.42–2.34 (m, 1H), 1.83–1.74 (m, 2H), 1.65–1.56 (m, 2H), 1.53–1.44 (m, 2H), 1.41–1.29 (m, 2H). 13C NMR (75 MHz, CD3OD): δ 160.0, 154.3, 154.0, 135.2, 113.7, 67.3, 52.4, 30.3, 30.1, 24.1. HRMS (ESI) m/z (M + H) calcd for C14H22N7, 288.1931; found, 288.1929.

    Synthesis of 6-(4-Ethylpiperazin-1-yl)-9-(3-(4-ethylpiperazin-1-yl)propyl)-9H-purin-2-amine (5)

    1-(3-Chloropropyl)-4-ethylpiperazine (1.16 g, 6.06 mmol) was added to a stirred suspension of compound 3 (1.0 g, 4.04 mmol) and potassium carbonate (1.12 g, 8.08 mmol) in dry DMF, and the reaction mixture was heated for 12 h at 100 °C. Water was added to the reaction mixture. The aqueous solution was extracted with chloroform, and the organic layer was dried over Na2SO4 and evaporated under vacuum. The residue was purified by silica gel column chromatography eluting with 8% methanol in chloroform to give compound 5 as a light-brown liquid (65%). 1H NMR (600 MHz, CDCl3): δ 7.49 (s, 1H), 4.59 (s, 2H), 4.32–4.20 (m, 4H), 4.08 (t, J = 7.2 Hz, 2H), 2.56–2.55 (m, 6H), 2.48–2.45 (m, 8H), 2.32 (t, J = 7.2 Hz, 2H), 2.01–1.97 (m, 2H), 1.14–1.10 (m, 6H). 13C NMR (150 MHz, CDCl3): δ 159.2, 154.2, 153.0, 136.7, 115.0, 54.5, 53.0, 52.7, 52.5, 52.3, 41.1, 26.4, 11.9, 11.8. HRMS (ESI) m/z (M + H) calcd for C20H36N9, 402.3088; found, 402.3077. HPLC purity 98.55%.

    6-(4-Cyclopentylpiperazin-1-yl)-9-(3-(4-ethylpiperazin-1-yl)propyl)-9H-purin-2-amine (6)

    Compound 4 (1 g, 3.48 mmol) was dissolved in DMF solvent, and to it, 1-(3-chloropropyl)-4-ethylpiperazine (1 g, 5.22 mmol) and potassium carbonate (0.96 g, 6.96 mmol) were added. The reaction mixture was heated at 100 °C for 12 h. Water was added to the reaction mixture, the aqueous solution was extracted with CHCl3, and column chromatography was performed using the CH3OH and CHCl3 system to afford compound 6 as a brown liquid (84%). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ 7.45 (s, 1H), 4.61 (s, 2H), 4.28–4.15 (m, 4H), 4.04 (t, J = 6.8 Hz, 2H), 2.87 (t, J = 4.8 Hz, 2H), 2.56 (t, J = 5.2 Hz, 4H), 2.47–2.42 (m, 5H), 2.40–2.34 (m, 4H), 2.27 (t, J = 6.8 Hz, 4H), 1.98–1.91 (m, 2H), 1.86–1.81 (m, 2H), 1.69–1.63 (m, 2H), 1.54–1.49 (m, 2H), 1.04 (t, J = 7.2 Hz, 3H). 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3): δ 159.3, 154.2, 153.1, 136.7, 115.0, 68.1, 67.6, 54.6, 53.6, 53.1, 52.9, 52.5, 52.4, 46.1, 41.1, 30.4, 30.3, 26.5, 24.2, 24.1, 12.0. HRMS (ESI) m/z (M + H) cald for C23H40N9, 442.3401; found, 442.3405. HPLC purity 98.53%.

    Synthesis of N-Benzyl-6-(4-ethylpiperazin-1-yl)-9-(3-(4-ethylpiperazin-1-yl)propyl)-9H-purin-2-amine (7)

    Compound 5 (0.18 g, 0.44 mmol) and benzaldehyde (0.06 mL, 0.53 mmol) were dissolved in 5 mL of toluene, and the reaction was performed using general procedure A. The residue was purified by silica gel column chromatography to produce compound 7 as a semisolid (50%). 1H NMR (600 MHz, CDCl3): δ 7.46 (s, 1H), 7.37 (d, J = 7.2 Hz, 2H), 7.30 (t, J = 7.2 Hz, 2H), 7.23 (t, J = 7.2 Hz, 1H), 5.03 (t, J = 5.4 Hz, 1H), 4.62 (d, J = 6 Hz, 2H), 4.29–4.16 (m, 4H), 4.07 (t, J = 6.6 Hz, 2H), 2.54–2.52 (m, 6H), 2.45–2.40 (m, 10H), 2.30 (t, J = 6.6 Hz, 2H), 1.99–1.95 (m, 2H), 1.12 (t, J = 7.2 Hz, 3H), 1.08 (t, J = 7.2 Hz, 3H). 13C NMR (150 MHz, CDCl3): δ 159.0, 154.2, 153.4, 140.6, 136.5, 128.5, 127.7, 127.0, 114.9, 54.7, 53.1, 52.9, 52.8, 52.6, 52.4, 46.2, 41.2, 26.6, 12.0. HRMS (ESI) m/z (M + H) calcd for C27H42N9, 492.3558; found, 492.3558. HPLC purity 99.94%.

    Synthesis of 6-(4-Ethylpiperazin-1-yl)-9-(-3-(4-ethylpiperazin-1-yl)propyl)-N-(4-methoxybenzyl)-9H-purin-2-amine (8)

    Compound 5 (0.30 g, 0.74 mmol) and 4-methoxybenzaldehyde (0.10 mL, 0.89 mmol) were dissolved in toluene (5 mL), and the reaction was performed according to general procedure A. Column chromatography was performed to obtain the pure product of 8 as a semisolid (46%). 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3): δ 7.46 (s, 1H), 7.29 (d, J = 8.4 Hz, 2H), 6.84 (d, J = 8.4 Hz, 2H), 4.96 (t, J = 5.7 Hz, 1H), 4.53 (d, J = 5.7 Hz, 2H), 4.32–4.14 (m, 4H), 4.07 (t, J = 6.6 Hz, 2H), 3.78 (s, 3H), 2.54–2.51 (m, 4H), 2.46–2.37 (m, 10H), 2.30 (t, J = 6.6 Hz, 2H), 2.13–2.03 (m, 2H), 2.01–1.93 (m, 2H), 1.12–1.04 (m, 6H). 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3): δ 158.8, 158.5, 153.9, 153.2, 136.2, 132.4, 128.8, 114.6, 113.7, 55.2, 54.6, 52.9, 52.6, 52.5, 52.4, 52.2, 45.3, 41.0, 26.3, 11.8, 11.6. HRMS (ESI) m/z (M + H) calcd for C28H44N9O, 522.3663; found, 522.3663. HPLC purity 99.80%.

    Synthesis of 6-(4-Ethyl piperazin-1-yl)-9(3-(4-ethylpiperazin-1-yl)propyl)-N-(4 fluorobenzyl)-9H-purin-2-amine (9)

    Compound 5 (0.30 g, 0.74 mmol) and 4-fluorobenzaldehyde (0.23 g, 0.88 mmol) were dissolved in toluene (5 mL), and the reaction was performed according to the general procedure A. HRMS (ESI) m/z (M + H) calcd for C27H41FN9, 510.3463; found, 510.3473. HPLC purity 99.91%.

    Synthesis of N-(4-(Diethylamino)benzyl)-6-(4-ethylpiperazin-1-yl)-9-(3-(4-ethylpiperazin-1-yl)propyl)-9H-purin-2-amine (10)

    Compound 5 (0.18 g, 0.44 mmol) and 4-diethylamino benzaldehyde (0.06 mL, 0.53 mmol) were dissolved in toluene (5 mL), and the reaction was performed using general procedure A.     Synthesis of N-(6-(4-Ethylpiperazin-1-yl)-9-(3-(4-ethylpiperazin-1-yl)propyl)-9H-purin-2-yl)benzamide (11)

    Benzoyl chloride (0.17 mL, 1.50 mmol) was added to a stirred solution of compound 5 (0.20 g, 0.50 mmol) and pyridine (0.24 mL, 3.0 mmol) in DCM. The mixture was stirred at room temperature for 10 h. The solvent was removed under vacuum, extracted with chloroform, washed with NaHCO3, dried over Na2SO4, and evaporated under vacuum. The residue was purified by silica gel column chromatography to provide compound 11 as a semisolid (60%). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ 8.31 (s, 1H), 7.85 (d, J = 8.4 Hz, 2H), 7.63 (s, 1H), 7.51–7.47 (m, 1H), 7.43–7.40 (m, 2H), 4.40–4.25 (m, 4H), 4.15 (t, J = 6.8 Hz, 2H), 2.53–2.51 (m, 8H), 2.45–2.37 (m, 8H), 2.28 (t, J = 6.8 Hz, 2H), 2.03–1.98 (m, 2H), 1.10–1.03 (m, 6H). 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3): δ 165.5, 153.8, 152.3, 138.6, 135.3, 131.9, 128.7, 127.5, 117.3, 54.5, 52.9, 52.8, 52.7, 52.5, 52.3, 41.5, 26.4, 11.9, 11.8. HRMS (ESI) m/z (M + H) calcd for C27H40N9O, 506.3350; found, 506.3338. HPLC purity 99.96%.

    Synthesis of 6-(4-Ethylpiperazin-1-yl)-9(-3-(4-ethylpiperazin-1-yl))propyl-2-(pyrrolidin-1-yl)-9H-purine (12)

    Compound 5 (0.20 g, 0.50 mmol) was dissolved in DMF (5 mL), cooled to 0 °C, and NaH (0.02 g, 0.75 mmol) was added to the solution. After 1 h, 1,4-dibromobutane (0.07 mL, 0.60 mmol) was added and the reaction was stirred under the N2 atmosphere condition at 80 °C for 12 h. Water was added to the reaction mixture and extracted with CHCl3. Column chromatography was performed using the CHCl3 system to obtain the compound 12 as a semisolid (30%). 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3): δ 7.41 (s, 1H), 4.37–4.20 (m, 4H), 4.07 (t, J = 6.9 Hz, 2H), 3.57–3.48 (m, 4H), 2.56–2.53 (m, 6H), 2.48–2.39 (m, 10H), 2.31 (t, J = 6.9 Hz, 2H), 2.04–1.97 (m, 2H), 1.97–1.89 (m, 4H), 1.13–1.06 (m, 6H). 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3): δ 157.7, 153.9, 135.9, 113.7, 54.8, 53.1, 52.8, 52.7, 52.6, 52.4, 46.8, 44.8, 41.1, 26.5, 25.7, 11.4. HRMS (ESI) m/z (M + H) calcd for C24H42N9, 456.3558; found, 456.3558. HPLC purity 99.98%.

    Synthesis of 6-(4-Cyclopentylpiperazin-1-yl)-9-(3-(4-ethylpiperazin-1-yl)propyl)-N-(4-methoxybenzyl)-9H-purin-2-amine (13)

    Compound 6 (0.20 g, 0.45 mmol) and 4-methoxybenzaldehyde (0.06 mL, 0.54 mmol) were dissolved in toluene (5 mL), and the reaction was performed using general procedure A. The residue was purified by silica gel column chromatography to afford compound 13 as a semisolid (51%). 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3): δ 7.45 (s, 1H), 7.29 (d, J = 8.4 Hz, 2H), 6.85 (d, J = 8.4 Hz, 2H), 5.00 (t, J = 5.4 Hz, 1H), 4.54 (d, J = 5.7 Hz, 2H), 4.35–4.21 (m, 4H), 4.08 (t, J = 6.9 Hz, 2H), 3.80 (s, 3H), 2.65 (m, 4H), 2.57–2.53 (m, 8H), 2.35 (t, J = 6.6 Hz, 2H), 2.03–1.97 (m, 3H), 1.92–1.90 (m, 2H), 1.76–1.71 (m, 2H), 1.58–1.50 (m, 4H), 1.16 (t, J = 7.2 Hz, 3H). 13C NMR (150 MHz, CDCl3): δ 158.8, 158.6, 153.9, 153.2, 136.3, 132.5, 128.9, 114.7, 113.8, 67.6, 55.3, 54.6, 52.6, 52.5, 52.4, 52.3, 45.5, 41.1, 30.3, 29.7, 26.4, 24.1, 11.6. HRMS (ESI) m/z (M + H) calcd for C31H48N9O, 562.3976; found, 562.3967. HPLC purity 98.74%.

    Synthesis of 6-(4-Cyclopentylpiperazin-1-yl)-9-(3-(4-ethylpiperazin-1-yl)propyl)-N-(4-fluorobenzyl)-9H-purin-2-amine (14)

    Compound 6 (0.20 g, 0.45 mmol) and 4-flurobenzaldehyde (0.06 mL, 0.54 mmol) were dissolved in toluene (5 mL), and the reaction was performed according to general procedure A.     Synthesis of 6-((4-Cyclopentylpiperazin-1-yl)-N-(4-diethylamino)benzyl)-9-(3-(4-ethylpiperazine-1-yl)propyl)-9H-purine-2-amine (15)

    Compound 6 (0.20 g, 0.45 mmol) and 4-diethyl aminobenzaldehyde (0.20 g, 0.54 mmol) were dissolved in toluene (5 mL), and the reaction was performed using general procedure A. Column chromatography was performed using the CHCl3/CH3OH system to obtain the pure product of 15 as a semisolid (55%). 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3): δ 7.45 (s, 1H), 7.20 (d, J = 8.7 Hz, 2H), 6.62 (d, J = 8.7 Hz, 2H), 4.94 (t, J = 5.4 Hz, 1H), 4.47 (d, J = 5.7 Hz, 2H), 4.39–4.20 (m, 4H), 4.09 (t, J = 6.6. HRMS (ESI) m/z (M + H) calcd for C34H55N10 603.4606; found, 603.4586. HPLC purity 97.60%.

    Synthesis of N-(6-(4-Cyclopentylpiperazin-1-yl)-9-(3-(4-ethylpiperazin-1-yl)propyl)-9H-purin-2-yl)-4-((dimethylamino)methyl)benzamide (16)

    A mixture of compound 6 (0.20 g, 0.45 mmol) and 4-((dimethylamino)methyl)benzoic acid (0.10 g, 0.54 mmol) was dissolved in dry pyridine (5 mL). POCl3 (0.06 mL, 0.68 mmol) was added to the solution at 0 °C, and the reaction was performed according to general procedure B. The residue was purified by silica gel column chromatography to give compound 16 as a gummy compound (53%). 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3): δ 8.30 (s, −NH), 7.87 (d, J = 8.1 Hz, 2H), 7.67 (s, 1H), 7.43 (d, J = 7.8 Hz, 2H), 4.22 (t, J = 6.6 Hz, 2H), 3.65 (s, 1H), 3.50 (s, 2H), 2.64–2.63 (m, 8H), 2.57–2.53 (m, 8H), 2.37 (t, J = 6.6 Hz, 2H), 2.27 (s, 6H), 2.06 (t, J = 6.6 Hz, 2H), 1.95–1.82 (m, 4H), 1.77–1.67 (m, 2H), 1.59–1.44 (m, 4H), 1.15 (t, J = 7.2 Hz, 3H). 13C NMR (150 MHz, CDCl3): δ153.6, 152.3, 138.4, 129.4, 127.5, 122.6, 121.1, 117.3, 116.3, 67.6, 63.8, 62.9, 52.4, 52.2, 45.3, 41.4, 37.1, 32.0, 30.3, 30.1, 29.7, 29.4, 26.4, 24.1, 22.7, 14.1. HRMS (ESI) m/z (M + H) calcd for C34H55N10, 603.4242; found, 603.4233. HPLC purity 99.29%.

    Synthesis of 6-Chloro-9-(3-(4-ethylpiperazin-1-yl)propyl)-9H-purin-2-amine (17)

    Compound 2 (1.0 g, 5.90 mmol) was dissolved in DMF (8 mL) and stirred for 2–3 h under a N2 atmosphere condition at 120 °C to obtain a clear solution. 1-(3-Chloropropyl)-4-ethylpiperazine (1.69 g, 8.85 mmol) and potassium carbonate (1.63 g, 11.80 mmol) were added to the reaction mixture and stirred for 12 h. Water was added to the reaction, and the organic layer was separated with CHCl3. Column chromatography was performed using the CHCl3/CH3OH system to obtain the compound 17 as a thick gummy liquid (65%). 1H NMR (300 MHz, DMSO-d6): δ 8.07 (s, 1H), 6.85 (s, 2H), 4.04 (t, J = 6.6 Hz, 2H), 2.25 (q, J = 7.2 Hz, 2H), 2.21 (t, J = 6.6 Hz, 3H), 1.92–1.88 (m, 2H), 0.94 (t, J = 7.2 Hz, 3H). 13C NMR (150 MHz, DMSO-d6): δ 160.2, 154.7, 149.7, 143.9, 123.9, 55.2, 53.0, 52.7, 52.1, 42.0, 26.2, 12.4. HRMS (ESI) m/z (M + H) calcd for C14H23ClN7, 324.1698; found, 324.1702.

    Synthesis of (4-(2-Amino-9-(3-(4-ethylpiperazin-1-yl)propyl)-9H-purin-6-yl)piperazin-1-yl)(phenyl)methanone (18)

    Compound 17 (2.0 g, 6.18 mmol) was dissolved in acetonitrile (10 mL). To the solution, phenyl(piperazine-1-yl) methanone (1.76 g, 9.27 mmol) and potassium carbonate (1.71 g, 12.36 mmol) were added. The reaction was refluxed for 4 hours. Completion of the reaction was monitored by TLC. Acetonitrile was evaporated and the reaction mixture was extracted using CHCl3 followed by column chromatography to obtain the pure product 18 as a liquid (86%). 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3): δ 7.48 (s, 1H), 7.44–7.37 (m, 5H), 4.68 (s, 2H), 4.40–4.13 (m, 4H), 4.08 (t, J = 6.6 Hz, 2H), 3.95–3.78 (m, 2H), 3.67–3.46 (m, 2H), 2.60–2.41 (m, 10H), 2.31 (t, J = 6.6 Hz, 2H), 2.03–1.94 (m, 2H), 1.09 (t, J = 7.2 Hz, 3H). 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3): δ 170.6, 159.1, 154.2, 153.2, 137.0, 135.6, 129.9, 128.6, 127.1, 115.1, 54.4, 52.5, 52.4, 52.3, 52.2, 41.1, 26.3, 11.6. HRMS (ESI) m/z (M + H) calcd for C25H36N9O, 478.3037; found, 478.3024. HPLC purity 99.88%.

    Synthesis of (4-(2-Amino-9-(3-(4-ethylpiperazin-1-yl)propyl)-9H-purin-6-yl)piperazin-1-yl)(cyclopentyl)methanone (19)

    Compound 17 (2.0 g, 6.18 mmol) was dissolved in acetonitrile (10 mL), and to the solution were added cyclopentyl(piperazine-1-yl)methanone (1.69 g, 9.27 mmol) and potassium carbonate (1.71 g, 12.36 mmol). The reaction was refluxed for 4 h. Acetonitrile was evaporated and the reaction mixture was extracted using CHCl3 followed by column chromatography to afford compound 19 as a gummy compound (78%). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ 7.48 (s, 1H), 4.63 (s, 2H), 4.26–4.19 (m, 4H), 4.07 (t, J = 6.8 Hz, 2H), 3.73–3.68 (m, 2H), 3.64–3.57(m, 2H), 2.94–2.85 (m, 1H), 2.57–2.44 (m, 8 H), 2.32 (t, J = 6.8 Hz, 2H), 2.25–2.15 (m, 2 H), 2.00–1.95 (m, 2H), 1.85–1.79 (m, 4H), 1.74–1.70 (m, 2H), 1.59–1.52 (m, 2H), 1.09 (t, J = 6.01, 3H). 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3): δ 159.2, 154.3, 153.2, 137.0, 115.1, 54.5, 52.7, 52.6, 52.3, 41.2, 30.2, 26.4, 26.2, 11.7. HRMS (ESI) m/z (M + H) calcd for C24H40N9O, 470.3350; found, 470.3331. HPLC purity 99.89%.

    Synthesis of (4-(9-(3-(4-Ethylpiperazin-1-yl)propyl)-2-((4-methoxybenzyl)amino)-9H-purin-6-yl)piperazin-1-yl)(phenyl)methanone (20)

    Compound 18 (0.20 g, 0.42 mmol) and 4-methoxybenzaldehyde (0.05 mL, 0.51 mmol) were dissolved in toluene (5 mL), and the reaction was performed according to general procedure A. The residue was purified by silica gel column chromatography to afford compound 20 as a semisolid (66%). 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3): δ 7.28 (s, 1H), 7.27–7.25 (m, 5H), 7.11 (d, J = 8.4 Hz, 2H), 6.67 (d, J = 8.7 Hz, 2H), 5.09 (s, 1H), 4.36 (d, J = 5.4 Hz, 2H), 4.22–4.04 (m, 4H), 3.91 (t, J = 6.6 Hz, 2H), 3.78–3.68 (m, 2H), 3.62 (s, 3 H), 3.42–3.24 (m, 2H), 2.59–2.34 (m, 10H), 2.18 (t, J = 6.6 Hz, 2H), 1.82–1.69 (m, 2H), 0.96 (t, J = 7.2, 3H). 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3 + 1 drop CD3OD): δ 176.5, 171.0, 158.7, 158.6, 154.0, 153.1, 136.8, 135.2, 132.3, 130.1, 128.6, 127.0, 114.4, 113.8, 55.3, 54.3, 51.7, 51.3, 50.9, 45.2, 41.2, 26.1, 22.3, 10.1. HRMS (ESI) m/z (M + H) calcd for C33H44N9O2, 598.3612; found, 598.3597. HPLC purity 97.97%.

    Synthesis of (4-(9-(3-(4-Ethylpiperazin-1-yl)propyl)-2-((4-fluorobenzyl)amino)-9H-purin-6-yl)piperazin-1-yl)(phenyl)methanone (21)

    Compound 18 (0.20 g, 0.42 mmol) and 4-flurobenzaldehyde (0.06 mL, 0.51 mmol) were dissolved in toluene (5 mL), and the reaction was performed using general procedure A. HRMS (ESI) m/z (M + H) calcd for C32H41FN9O, 586.3413; found, 586.3394. HPLC purity 99.26%.

    (4-(2-(4-(Diethylamino)benzyl)amino-9-(3-(4-ethylpiperazin-1-yl)propyl)-9H-purine-6-yl)piperazin-1-yl)(phenyl)methanone (22)

    Compound 18 (0.20 g, 0.42 mmol) and 4-diethyl aminobenzaldehyde (0.10 g, 0.51 mmol) were dissolved in toluene (5 mL), and the reaction was performed according to general procedure A.     Synthesis of (4-(9-(3-(4-Ethylpiperazin-1-yl)propyl)-2-(pyrrolidin-1-yl)-9H-purin-6-yl)piperazin-1-yl)(phenyl)methanone (23)

    Compound 18 (0.25 g, 0.52 mmol) was dissolved in dry DMF (5 mL), and the reaction mixture was cooled to −10 °C. To the mixture was added NaH (0.02 g, 1.4 mmol). The reaction mixture was allowed to stir for 1 hour at the cold condition. Then, 1,4-dibromobutane (0.06 g, 0.52 mmol) was added to it and allowed to stir for a further 12 h under a N2 atmosphere at 80 °C. Water was added to the reaction mixture, and it was extracted with CHCl3. Column chromatography was performed using the CHCl3 system to obtain compound 23 as a semisolid (35%). 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3): δ 7.47–7.39 (m, 6H), 4.37–4.18 (m, 4H), 4.09 (t, J = 6.9, 2H), 3.94–3.81 (m, 2H), 3.64–3.43 (m, 6H), 2.59–2.42 (m, 10H), 2.32 (t, J = 6.9, 2H), 2.03–1.99 (m, 2H), 1.96–1.89 (m, 4H), 1.0 (t, J = 7.2 Hz, 3H). 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3): δ 170.6, 153.8, 145.5, 141.5, 136.0, 135.6, 129.8, 128.5, 127.1, 56.5, 56.4, 54.4, 52.3, 52.1, 52.0, 51.8, 49.8, 46.7, 41.0, 26.1, 25.6, 12.6. HRMS (ESI) m/z (M + H) calcd for C29H42N9O, 532.3507; found, 532.3517. HPLC purity 99.63%.
